Expectation1: Communicate clearly and empathetically with patients and their families
Situation1: A patient has received a new diagnosis for a chronic condition and has many questions about managing it.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: They are the only volunteer assigned to unlock the facility and begin the service for people already waiting outside.
Story: I glanced at the clock on the wall, feeling the minutes slip away faster than I could answer the patient’s questions. She sat across from me, her eyes wide with worry, clutching the pamphlet I’d just handed her about her new diagnosis. I knew she needed more than just information—she needed reassurance, a clear plan, and someone to listen. I wanted to give her all of that, to be the doctor she deserved. But my phone buzzed with a reminder: my volunteer shift started in ten minutes. I was the only one scheduled to unlock the community center this morning, and I pictured the line of people already waiting outside, counting on me to open the doors and start the day’s service. My heart pounded as I tried to balance the urge to stay and support my patient with the responsibility I felt toward the people waiting at the center. Both roles demanded my presence, my care, and my time, but I couldn’t be in two places at once. I felt the weight of their expectations pressing in, and I hesitated, torn between the needs of one and the needs of many.
